File.Title: The Tectorecipient Zone in the Inferior Olivary Nucleus in the Rat

Abstract.S: Tecto-olivary and olivocerebellar projections in the rat were investigated in order to identify the tectorecipient zone in the inferior olivary nucleus and to determine whether inferior olivary neurons projecting to the cerebellar tecto-olivo-recipient zones (lobule VII, crus 11, lobulus simplex, and paramedian lobule) originate in the different regions within the tectorecipient zone.
An electrophysiological method and an axonal transport technique of wheat-germ agglutinin-conjugated horseradish peroxidase were used.
The tectorecipient zone was identified in the caudomedial region of the medial accessory olive.
Neurons projecting to lobule VII originated in the caudomedial region of the tectorecipient zone, but those to crus 11, lobulus simplex, and paramedian lobule originated in its rostrolateral region.

These observations suggest that there are two independent tecto-olivo-cerebellar systems: 1) superior colliculus-the medial region of the tectorecipient zone-lobule VII-the caudomedial region of the fastigial nucleus; and 2) superior colliculus-the rostrolateral region of the tectorecipient region-crus 11, lobulus simplex, and paramedian lobule-the dorsolateral protuberance of the fastigial nucleus.

Introduction.S: Olivocerebellar fibers terminate in longitudinally oriented zones in the cerebellar cortex.
These zones are parts of efferent compartments of the cerebellum.
It is likely that each has a specific function in motor control (for reviews: Oscarsson, '80; Brodal and Kawamura, '80; Voogd and Bigark, '80).

Inferior olivary (10) neurons in a tectorecipient (TR) zone are known to project to the vermal region of lobule VII in the rat (Brown, '80; Hess, '82; Wiklund et al., '84; Huerta and Harting, '84b; Akaike, '85), the rabbit (Brodal, '40), the cat (Brodal, '40; Hoddevik et al., '76; Kawamura and Hashikawa, '79; Jeneskog, '81, '83), and the primate (Frankfurter et al., '77; Brodal and Brodal, '81; Ikeda et al., '89).

The TR zone is almost the same in all these animals, that is, the caudomedial region of the medial accessory olive (MAO) in the contralateral side in the rat (Hess, '82; Swenson and Castro, '83; Huerta and Harting, '84b), the cat (Weber et al., '78; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '81, '82; Huerta and Harting, '84b; Kyuhou and Matsuzaki, '91), and the primate (Frankfurter et al., '76; Huerta and Harting, '84b).

Climbing fiber responses could, however, be evoked in the rat in a longitudinal strip in the medial region of crus I1 and lobulus simplex (LS) by stimulation of the deeper layers of the superior colliculus (SC) (Akaike, '86b,c, '87).
Some were also evoked by stimulation of trigeminal nerves (Akaike, '88).
These observations suggest that the TR zone can be further divided into two functional sectors, and that there are two independent tecto-olivo-cerebellar projections.

The present study was undertaken in order to identify the TR zone in the I0 nucleus and to investigate whether or not I0 neurons projecting to tecto-olivo-recipient (TOR) zones in the cerebellar cortex originate exclusively and differentially in the TR zone.
The results are composed of two sections: 1) the tectorecipient zone; and 2) olivocerebellar neurons.
Observations using an electrophysiological method and an axonal transport technique will be described.
Neuronal connections and physiological functions of the tecto-olivary and the olivocerebellar projections will be discussed.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Electrophysiology
Fifty male adult rats (Wistar, 200-400 g, body weight, from the Japan SLC Company, Hamamatsu), were used.
They were anesthetized with chloral hydrate (40 mg/ml HzO, 0.5-1.0 ml/lOO g B.W., intraperitoneally).
Deep levels of anesthesia were kept through additional doses.
They were cannulated, immobilized with gallamine triethiodide, and respirated artificially.
Their body temperature was maintained by using a heating pad.
After they were mounted on a stereotaxic apparatus (Narishige, Tokyo), the caudal portion of the skull was removed.
Occipital regions of the cerebrum, the cerebellum, and upper parts of the spinal cord were exposed, and covered with a mixture of warmed vaseline and liquid paraffin.
Bar holes were made in the midline of the skull at the level of bregma.

A monopolar metal electrode (0.2-0.3 mm in diameter, insulated except at the tip) was placed in the deeper layers of the SC, 2.0-3.0 mm rostra1 from the interaural line (IAL; Paxinos and Watson, '86), 1.5-2.0 mm lateral from the midline of the brain, and 3.5-4.0 mm deep from the surface of the cerebral cortex (Figs. 1,2).
Depth of the electrode was adjusted to evoke maximum amplitude of climbing fiber responses in lobule VII and/or crus I1 in the ipsilateral side.
The tectal stimulation was most effective when it was placed just lateral to the central gray under the SC (Fig. 2A).
It is consistent with the fact that tecto-olivary fibers gather along the lateral side of the central gray and cross the midline as the predorsal bundle (PDB).
A bipolar electrode (separated 1.5-2.0 mm between the tips) was placed at optic nerves using perpendicular penetration through the cerebral cortex.
This electrode was used to identify visual response areas of the I 0 nucleus (Akaike, '86a).
Tectal response areas in the MA0 could be reached in reference to the visual response areas (Akaike, '86c).
Bipolar electrodes (separated 5-7 mm between the tips) were placed subcutaneously on both sides to stimulate trigeminal nerves in the whisker region.

These electrodes were used to identify the TR zone since stimulation of the trigeminal nerves was effective in evoking excitation of I 0 neurons in the TR zone in the ipsilateral side (Akaike, '88, '89).

One to three bipolar electrodes were placed at a time in cerebellar cortices (lobule VII, crus 11, LS b, and/or PML) where the tectal climbing fiber responses were identified, to evoke antidromic action potentials in the I 0 nucleus in the contralateral side.
Single or double shocks (rectangular pulses, 0.2 ms in duration, 0.5-3.0 ms interval, current of 50-600 FA, and 0.2-1.0 Hz) were derived from isolation units.
For stimuli to the SC, the cerebellar cortices, and the optic nerves, currents (50-300 FA; usually below 200 FA) were applied.
The trigeminal nerves were stimulated by double shocks (300-600 FA) subcutaneously.
Glass micropipettes having electric resistance of 5-10 MR and filled with 2 N NaCl (usually saturated with Fastgreen FCF) were used.
They were connected to a neutralized preamplifier and then to a storage type of oscilloscope (ATAC-250, Nihonkohden, Tokyo).
Vertical penetration from the midline to 1.0 mm lateral, and 2.0-6.0 mm caudal to the IAL was used.
Oblique penetration occurred sometimes.
Responses were photographed.
After experiments the sites recorded and stimulated were examined histologically.
Histology
After the 20 anesthetized rats were mounted on the stereotaxic apparatus, bar holes were made to expose the cerebellar cortex, and/or occipital regions of the cerebral cortex.
The enzyme wheat germ agglutinin-conjugated horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP, Sigma) was dissolved in saline (1040%).
Glass pipettes filled with the WGA-HRP solution were placed in the SC stereotaxically, or in lobule VII, crus 11, LS b, or PML under the visual control (Fig. 2).
Climbing fiber responses by the tectal stimulation were identified before injection.

After 12-24 hours, the rats were deeply anesthetized and perfused transcardially through a cannula inserted in the ascending aorta by saline (400-600 ml), followed by fixatives (400-600 ml; 1% paraformaldehyde, and 1.25% glutaraldehyde or 10% formalin in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4) and then 10-20% sucrose solution in the same phosphate buffer (100-200 ml).
The brain was removed and stored for 3-12 hours in the same sucrose solution (4Â°C).
The brain was sliced into sections 40-100 pm thick on a freezing microtome, and collected in compartmentalized trays.
They were treated with tetramethylbenzidine following the procedure described by Mesulam ('78).
To analyze the results, a standard map of the I0 nucleus (2.5 mm long anteroposteriorly, and 1.1 mm wide mediolaterally), and an unfolded diagram of the MA0 were made (Fig. 3).

Results.S: RESULTS
The tectorecipient zone
Electrophysiology.
A recording electrode was lowered vertically through the cerebellum and into the medulla oblongata at 0.85 mm rostral to the obex, and at 0.05-0.6 mm lateral from the midline.
The tectal stimulation was given in the contralateral side.
Evoked potentials typical of excitation of I0 neurons were identified at depths of 2.6-2.9 mm from the surface of the medulla (0.3-1.5 mV amplitudes, latency 4.0-10.0 ms).
A tectal response area identified in one transverse plane of the MA0 is illustrated in Figure 4.
The tectal response area extends from the midline to 0.5 mm lateral in the plane.
In another experiment a recording electrode was moved rostrocaudally in one parasagittal plane (0.15 mm lateral from the midline).
Averaged amplitudes of evoked potentials were observed (ten times, 0.3-1.0 Hz) by stimulation of the optic nerves, the contralateral SC, lobule VII, or crus 11.
Numbers measured are indicated at each recording site in Figure 5.
In the caudal region of the I0 nucleus, responses evoked by stimulation of the optic nerves were predominantly recorded.
Histological examination indicated that visual response areas were the whole area of nucleus @, a caudal half of the dorsal cap, and part of the caudomedial MAO.
By advancing the recording electrode 0.1 mm rostrally, tectal responses appeared in the MA0 under the visual response area of nucleus f3.
The tectal response area extended 0.5-0.6 mm rostrocaudally on the parasagittal plane.
Antidromic responses will be described later.
To survey tectal response areas in whole, a systematic tracking of one recording electrode was made every 100 km rostrocaudally and mediolaterally.
In the caudal halves of nucleus p and the dorsal cap, visual responses dominated (planes 8,9; Fig. 6).
A small tectal response was identified at the lateral side of a visual response area (plane 8).
Visual responses considerably decreased in the rostral halves of nucleus p and the dorsal cap.
In the MAO, large tectal responses were recorded from the medial side to 0.3-0.5 mm lateral (planes 3-7).
In the rostral planes (1, 2) small tectal responses were identified at the medial side of the MA0 (not illustrated).
The tectal response area extended from the medial side to 0.5 mm lateral and 0.6-0.7 mm long rostrocaudally in the MAO.
Tectal responses were investigated on the horizontal plane in another experiment.
The largest response in each penetration is shown at the respective recording site (Fig. 7).
The tectal response area extended 0.5-0.6 mm rostrocaudally and 0.4-0.5 mm mediolaterally.
The tectal response areas identified in the contralateral side in these experiments could be regarded as the TR zone.
They were in subnucleus c.
When the tectal stimulation was given in the recording side, evoked potentials as large as visual responses were identified in the visual response area of the I 0 nucleus in the above experiments.
None was identified in area of the TR zone in the same side.
The finding suggested that those responses were evoked by stimulation of the visual pretectoolivary pathways in the mesencephalon (Akaike, 86a; see Discussion).
Histology.
One case, with representative anterograde labeling of terminals of tecto-olivary fibers in the I 0 nucleus, was chosen from experiments on six rats (Fig. 8).

TTE.S: The tracer was injected in the rostrolateral region of the SC, with relatively low density of current (10 FA, 8 seconds on18 seconds off, 20 minutes, Fig. 2B).
Four of ten coronal sections which contain labeled areas in the contralateral MA0 are illustrated in A-D, Figure 8.
In the rostral plane (A) the medial side of the MA0 is labeled.
In the caudal plane (D) its middle region is labeled.
In the in-between planes (B and C), labeled areas extend from the medial side to 0.3-0.5 mm lateral in the MAO.

On the contralateral side of the tracer injection, neurons in the spinal trigeminal nucleus, pars interpolaris (Vi), pars oralis (Vo), principal trigeminal nucleus (Vp), cerebellar lateral (LN), interposed (IN), and medial nuclei (MN), SC, and spinal cord were labeled retrogradely, On the ipsilateral side neurons in the cerebral cortex were labeled retrogradely.
Trigeminorecipient zones of the I0 nucleus in the ipsilateral side were labeled anterogradely (not illustrated; see Discussion).

Results.S: In other experiments labeled areas and neurons were similar to those described for this case.
Olivocerebellar neurons
Electrophysiology.
Antidromically activated potentials were identified in one transverse plane of the MA0 following stimulation in vermis of lobule VII, or in the medial region of LS b or crus I1 (Fig. 9).
All antidromic responses were identified within the TR zone in the contralateral side (see Fig. 4).
The responses from lobule VII were identified in the medial region of the TR zone.
Those from crus I1 were identified in its lateral region.
Those from LS b were identified in almost the whole area of the TR zone on this coronal plane.
In one parasagittal plane (0.15 mm lateral from the midline, Fig. 51, an antidromic response area from lobule VII extended 0.2-0.3 mm just rostral to the visual response area in the MAO.
The responses from crus I1 were identified more rostral to the area from lobule VII.

To survey antidromic response areas in whole, a systematic tracking of one recording electrode was made every 100 pm rostrocaudally and mediolaterally in the caudomedial I 0 nucleus (Fig. 10; see Fig. 6).
Any antidromic potentials from lobule VII or crus 11 were not identified in the visual response areas in nucleus @, the dorsal cap, or the MA0 (planes 8,9).
The responses from lobule VII were identified in the medial region of the TR zone, and those from crus I1 were identified in its lateral region (planes 4-7).
In the rostra1 plane (31, antidromic responses were identified in the medial side and were exclusively from crus 11.
In another experiment antidromic response areas from lobule VII, crus 11, or LS b were surveyed on the horizontal plane.
The largest response in each penetration is illustrated at the respective recording site (Fig. 11).
The responses from lobule VII (3) were identified in the caudomedial region of the TR zone (2; see Fig. 7).
Those from LS b (4) or crus I1 (5) were identified in its rostrolateral region.
Histology.

TTE.S: The WGA-HRP solution was injected in vermis of lobule VII or in the medial region of crus 11, LS b, or PML where climbing fiber responses by the tectal stimulation were identified.
Two cases, showing representative retrograde labeling of I 0 neurons from lobule VII or crus I1 (Figs. 12, 13, respectively), were chosen from experiments on eight rats.
In lobule VII the tracer diffused across the midline (Fig. 2D); then labeled neurons were identified on both sides of the MAO.
They were all considered to be I 0 neurons projecting to lobule VII.
Their distribution ranged from the medial side to 0.35 mm lateral, and 0.3-0.4 mm long rostrocaudally (Fig. 12).
Neurons labeled retrogradely from crus I1 located more widely from the medial side to 0.5 mm lateral, and 0.5-0.6 mm long rostrocaudally in the MA0 in the contralateral side (Fig. 13).
In any other areas of the I0 nucleus labeled neurons were not identified.
When the tracer was injected in LS b or in PML, all labeled neurons were identified within the area of crus 11-projecting neurons (not illustrated).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Tectorecipient zone
The TR zone is defined as an area of the I 0 nucleus in which neurons receive synaptic influences directly from tectal neurons via the PDB.
In the present study it was identified in the caudomedial region of the MA0 in the contralateral side, extending at maximum 0.7-0.8 mm rostrocaudally and 0.5-0.6 mm laterally.
Inferior olivary neurons which projected to the TOR zones (lobule VII, crus 11, LS b, and PML) were identified exclusively in the TR zone of the MA0 in the present study (Fig. 14).
In view of the functional architecture, subnucleus c of the MA0 can be defined as the TR zone.
The area defined above may be in accordance with subnucleus c of other authors (Gwyn et al., 77; Azizi and Woodward, 87; Bernard, 87; Ruigrok and Voogd, 90; Apps, 90).
It may be subnucleus b of the MA0 in the primate (Brown and Sladek, 73; Whitworth and Haines, 83; Ikeda et al., 89).
However, the TR zone in the present study is wider than those identified by Hess ( 821, Swenson and Castro ( 831, mao -0.5 -
and Huerta and Harting ('84b).

According to their figures (Hess, '82, Fig. 3; Swenson and Castro, '83, Fig. 9; Huerta and Harting, '84b, Fig. 29), their zones are all similar, and smaller in width, and are identified in the most medial region of the MAO.
It is the same area as that of lobule VII-projecting neurons in the present study.
There are several possibilities by which the TR zone identified in this experiment is widened.
First, current stimuli applied to the SC may activate terminals of tectal afferents which have axon collaterals projecting to the I 0 nucleus.
Second, fibers projecting to the I 0 nucleus may be activated while passing in the mesencephalon.
Third, in addition to tecto-olivary fibers, the other mesencephaloolivary neurons are stimulated.

It may also be the case with the tracer experiment, that is, the tracer injected in the SC may be incorporated and transported to the I0 nucleus by the tectal afferents which have axon collaterals projecting to the I0 nucleus.
The tracer may be incorporated by the other mesencephalo-olivary neurons or by fibers passing in the SC which are projecting to the I0 nucleus.
Finally, the TR zone identified in the present study is correct.
Other authers might have injected the tracer in a restricted area of the SC, and then obtained smaller areas of the TR zone.

The SC has many afferents, among which there are several candidates that also project to the I0 nucleus, i.e., the cerebral cortex, the contralateral SC, the cerebellar nuclei, the spinal and principal trigeminal nuclei, the dorsal column nuclei, and the spinal cord (Stein, '81; Taylor et al., '86; see refs. in Huerta and Harting, '84b).
In the following discussion, these afferents will be examined by centering on their laterality and branching.
The ipsilateral side refers to the side of origin of neurons projecting to the SC.
Cerebral cortex.

Neurons in the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital cortices project to the superficial and/or the deeper layers of the SC exclusively in the ipsilateral side in the rat (Wise and Jones, '77; Beckstead, '79; Olavarria and van Sluyters, '82; Matsuyama and Kawamura, '85; Cadusseau and Roger, '85; Matute and Streit, '85; Hardy, '86; Leichnetz et al., '87; Leichnetz and Gonzalo-Ruiz, '87; Harvey and Worthington, '90).
Similarly, cerebral corticoolivary projections are mainly ipsilateral in the rat (Brown et al., '77; Swenson and Castro; '83; Swenson et al., '89).
Contralateral superior colliculus.

The majority of cells of origin of the PDB are identified in sublayer b of stratum griseum intermedium (SGI), but the majority of tectotectal cells are above and below this layer and project to the corresponding area in the opposite side in the rat (Yamasaki et al., '84; Bickford and Hall, '89).
Very few cells of origin of the PDB project to tectotectal pathways in the rat.

Tectoolivary projections which are part of the PIIB are almost exclusively contralateral in the rat (Brown et al., '77; Iless, '82; Swenson and Castro, '83; Huerta and Harting, '84b; Akaike, '85, '86~).
Cerebellar nuclei.
Neurons in the cerebellar LN, the lateral region of the IN. and the caudal MN project to the SGI of the SC in the contralateral side in the rat (Faull and Carman, '78; Bentivoglio and Kuypers. '82).
Those projecting to the SC in the ipsilateral side are very few.
GonzaloRuiz and Leichnetz ('87) and Gonzalo-Ruiz et al. ('90) reported that some cells in the MN, IN, and LN have axonal branchings, one projecting to the SC, the other to the brainstem.
The branching cells in the MN are idmtified in both sides, but there are more cells on the contralateral side.
Efferent fibers from the MN to the SC terminate bilaterally, but are heavier contralaterally.
However, cells in the PIN (not the MN) are the principal source of the cerebello-tectal projection to the SGI.
On the other hand, neurons in the caudal part of the MN project to nucleus b, or to the caudomedial MAO.
Other cerebello-olivary projections terminate in the rostral MAO, dorsal accessory olive (DAO), or principal olive (1'0) in the contralateral side in the rat.
The cerebello-olivary neurons are small.

The majority of them seem not to distribute axon collaterals to the mesencephalon, diencephalon, or spinal cord in the rat (Angaut and Cicirata, '82; Bentivoglio and Kuypers, '82; Swenson and Castro, '83; Ruigrok and L'oogd, ''30).
Spinal andprincipal trigerninal nuclei.
The overwhelming majority of trigeminal cells projecting to the SC are houstd in the Vi or Vp in the contralateral side.
Some cells in the Vp projecting to the contralatera1 side recross at the level of the SC commissure (Rhoades et a]., '89).

On the other hand, trigeminal cttlls in the Vi project to the rostral DAO or PO in the contralateral side in the rat (Cook and U'iesendanger, '76; Brown et al., '77; Swenson and Castro, '83; Huertn et al., '83; Akaike, '89).
Dorsal column nuclei and spinal cord.
Neurons in the dorsal column nuclei (DCN) project to the SC, particularly in the intercollicular region in the contralateral side in the rat (Feldman and Kruger, '80; Massopust et al., '85).
Neurons in the spinal cord project to the SC in the contralateral side in the rat (Antonetty and Webster, '75).

Neurons in the DCN or in the spinal cord project to the I)AO or PO in the contralateral side in the rat (Brown et al., '77; Swenson and Castro, '83), and the cat (Oscarsson and Sjolund, '77; Berkley and Hand, '78; Ekerot and Larson, '79; Armstrong and Schild, '80; Molinari, '85; Berkley et al., '86).
The six afferents discussed above all project to both the SC and the I0 nucleus in the same side: the cerebral cortex projects to the ipsilateral, and the others to the contralateral sides.
Some cells in the Vp or Vi may project to the SC in the ipsilateral side, but, as discussed above, there are only a few, if any.
Some cells in the caudal MN have axonal branchings and project to both the SC and the I 0 in the same side ipsilaterally or contralaterally, but only a few may have crossed branchings.
These arguments suggest that any afferents to the SC discussed above may not contribute significantly to widen the TR zone in the contralateral side.
Second, fibers passing in the vicinity of the SC may be involved in widening the TR zone.
Most probable candidates are pretecto-olivary projections in the rat (Brown et al., '77; Terasawa et al., '79; Giolli et al., '84; Akaike, '86a).
These projections to the I0 nucleus are all ipsilateral.

Third, many neurons in the mesodiencephalic junction, such as those in the parvocellular red nucleus, interstitd nucleus of Cajal, nucleus accessorius medialis of Bechterew, parafascicular and subparafascicular nuclei, nucleus of the field of Forel, and central gray, project to the I0 nucleus in the rat (Brown et al., '77; Swenson and Castro, '83; Rutherford et al., '841, and the cat (Ogawa, '39; Mabuchi and Kusama, '70; Saint-Cyr and Courville, '81; Onodera, '84).
These mesodiencephalic projections to the I0 nucleus are so far known all to be ipsilateral.
Thus these olivary afferents can be eliminated.
Therefore the TR zone identified in the present study seems to be correct.
Olivocerebellar projections
The I0 neurons projecting to lobule VII are identified in the TR zone in the rat (Hess, '82; Swenson and Castro, '83; Huerta and Harting '84b; Azizi and Woodward, '87; Sugita et al., '89; Apps, '90).

On the other hand, a few investigators noticed that some I0 neurons in subnucleus c are labeled when the tracer is injected in the medial crus 11, or PML (Brown, '80; Furber and Watson, '83; Wiklund et al., '84).
Akaike ('86c) was the first, using the electrophysiological method, to describe that neurons in the TR zone project to the medial region of crus 11.
However, a few authors did not notice any 10 neurons projecting to crus I1 in the caudomedial MA0 (hizi and Woodward, '87).
Other authors identified crus 11-projecting neurons in the lateral region of the subnucleus c of the MA0 (Buisseret-Delmas, '88; Apps, '90).
Branchings.
Branchings of climbing fibers are frequently observed along the longitudinal zones within the vermal region, or within the hemisphere, respectively (Eisenman and Goracci, '83; Wiklund et al., '84).
Akaike ('87) reported that climbing fiber responses are evoked in LS by stimulation of crus 11, and vice versa.
In contrast, no axonal branchings are identified which project both to crus I1 and to lobule VII.
The evidence indicates that climbing fibers to crus I1 have axon collaterals projecting to LS b, but no branchings projecting to lobule VII.

These observations suggest two independent olivocerebellar projection systems: one is the caudomedial section of the TR zonelobule VII; and the other is the rostrolateral section of the TR zone-crus I1 and/or LS b.
Tecto-oliuo-recipient zones in the cerebellum.
BuisseretDelmas ('88) described a new longitudinal zone in the cerebellar vermis spanning LS, crura I and 11, and PML (the lateral section of zone A).
Neurons projecting to the lateral section of zone A are identified in subnucleus c which is reguarded as the TR zone in the present study.

Based on the cortico-fastigial connections, the vermal zone A is divided into two sections: 1) the medial section of zone A-the caudomedial region of the medial nucleus (cmMN); and 2) the lateral section of zone A-the dorsolateral protuberance of the MN (Mdlp) (Armstrong and Schild, '78; Haines and Koletar, '79; Umetani et al., '86; BuisseretDelmas, '88; Palillysaho et al., '90).

This is in good accordance with two tecto-olivo-cerebellar systems in the present study: 1) the caudomedial region of the TR zone-lobule VII-cmMN; and 2) the rostrolateral region of the TR zone-crus 11, LS, and PML-Mdlp.
Functional considerations
Cerebellar nucleo-tectal connections.
There are two

cerebellar nucleo-tectal projections in the cat: neurons in the MN project to the deeper layers of the SC bilaterally, though more dominantly in the contralateral side, and neurons in the posterior IN (PIN) or in the LN project to the contralateral ventral half of the SGI or to a lesser extent in the deep layers of the SC (Roldan and Reinoso-Suarez, '81; Hirai et al., '82; Kawamura et al., '82; Suamoto et d., '82).

May and Hall ('86) emphasized species difference in that only the former pathway is reported in the monkey (Batton et al., '77; Chan-Palay, '77) while only the latter is found in the rabbit (Uchida et al., '83), the squirrel (May and Hall, '861, and the rat (Faull and Carman, '78).

Gonzalo-Ruiz and Leichnetz ('87) and Gonzalo-Ruiz et al., ('go), however, insisted that in the rat there are bilateral projections of the MN, but the contralateral is heavier, and that the cerebello-tectal connections are similar between the rat and the monkey.
Neurons in the Mdlp seem to project to the medulla, but neither to the SC nor to the thalamus (Bentivoglio and Kuypers, '82; Gonzalo-Ruiz and Leichnetz, '87).
Synaptic actions.
Tecto-olivary projections have excitatory synaptic actions, as shown above.

Climbing fibers may have two effects on Purkinje cells (P-cells): immediate strong facilitations followed by weak, long-lasting inhibitions of simple spikes (Eccles et al., '66, '67; Bloedel and Roberts, '71; Colin et al., '80; Montarolo et al., '82; Bardin et al., '83; Batini and Billard, '85).
They also send axon collaterals to cerebellar nuclei (Matsushita and Ikeda, '70; Chan-Palay '77; Van der Want and Voogd, '78).
By activation of climbing fibers, cerebellar nuclear cells may be excited, and then inhibited by P-cell bombardments.

They may then show rebound bursting activities caused by the preceding membrane hyperpolarization and by the disinhibition following, due to suppression of P-cell firing (Llinas and Miihlethaler, '88).
The majority of MN cells have excitatory synaptic actions on cells in the ventral medial (VM) thalamic nucleus (Eceles et al., '67; Kyuhou and Kawaguchi, '87).
However, another line of evidence suggests that nucleo-olivary projections are GABAergic, that is, inhibitory.
(Sotelo et al., '86; Anderson et al., '88; Angaut and Sotelo, '89).
Saccade and orienting responses.

In respect to motor activities, stimulation of the SC evokes saccades, head and body movements directed to the opposite side of stimulation in the rat (Stein, '81; McHaffie and Stein, '82; Sahibzaba et al., '86; Dean et al., '891, the cat (Sprague et al., '73; Guitton et al., '80; Harris, '80; Roucoux et al., '80; McIlwain, '861, and the primate (Robinson, '72).

Stimulation of P-cells in lobule VII evokes saccades directed to the stimulating side, but stimulation of the fastigial oculomotor region (FOR; target of P-cells in lobule VII) evokes saccades directed to the opposite side in the primate (Noda and Fujikado, '87; Fujikadao and Noda, '87; Noda et al., '88).
The fact that saccades evoked by stimulation of the P-cells have a direction opposite to those of the FOR is in good agreement with their opposite synaptic actions.
Activation of cells of origin of the tecto-olivo-cerebellar pathway can evoke excitation of cells in the FOR and inhibition of P-cells in lobule VII on the same side.
Therefore direction of saccades evoked by the SC may be the same evoked by the cerebellum, ifpossible, through the tecto-olivocerebellar pathway.
The MN(F0R)-SC projections are, however, not as prominent as those described before, and the saccade generation mechanism in the cerebellum is relatively independent from that of the SC.
(Yamada and Noda, '87; Noda et al., '90; Sugita and Noda, '91).
These considerations suggest that the tecto-olivo-cerebellar pathway may inform the cerebellum of generation of a command of saccade in the SC.
It makes both P-cells in lobule VII and cells in the FOR support the command generated in the SC, or it restrains them from generating another saccade at a time.
In the rat. receptive fields of P-cells or of mossy fibers in lobule VII are not identified.
However, their receptive fields in crus 11, LS b, and PML are around the perioral region which is employed in instinctive and exploring behaviors (Shambes et al., '78a,b).

These considerations suggest that the lateral section of zone A (crus 11, LS b, and PML)Mdlp is involved in orienting the perioral region to a target, whereas its medial section (lobule VI1)-cmMN may be involved in orienting the eye, head, and body.
Tecto-thalamo-striatal connections.

Cells of origin of the PDB have branches ascending to the intralaminar nuclei (ILN) in the rat (Chevalier and Deniau, '84; Yamasaki et al., '86; Redgrave et al., '86; Bickford and Hall, '891, the cat (Graham, '77; Kaufman and Rosenquist, '85b; Graybiel, '771, and the primate (Partlow et al., '77; Harting et al., '80).

The ILN are thought to be a center for attention orientation (Kaufman and Rosenquist, '85a,b; Albe-Fessard et al., '85) or a relay station from the brainstem orienting mechanism to the motor areas of the cerebral cortex and the striatum in the rat (Jones and Leavitt, '74; Van der Kooy, '79; Veening et al., '80; Herkenham, '80; Ullan, '85; Olausson et al., '891, the cat (Itoh and Mizuno, '77; Royce, '78; Sat0 et al., '79; Beckstead, '84; Macchi et al., '84; Merker and Schlag, '851, and the primate (Kievit and Kuypers, '77; Parent et al., '83; Brysch et al., '84).
The orienting responses, assigned to the SC, may be carried out by cooperation with the cerebellum and the ILN-basal ganglia.
